revisionDesc.change: moved remaining notes to external file and added ptrs; checked
Proofreading Corrections: Heyde dates and Silent Proof
Moved RMBucke to HandNote; fixed editor, date, and title; reviewed paragraphing
Replaced smart quotes with straight; removed external URL links.
Changed straight quotes to chararacter reference smart quotes.
Proofread based on Ransom copy and removed some cuts which are identifiable in original.

Dated letter to February 6 based on visit of Prince Arthur, son of Queen Victoria, to Brooklyn and profile of visit in Daily Eagle. Annotated the poem deemed a "christmas present" to Abby Hills Price. Corrected transcription based on oral proofreading.

body.p: i received your letter yesterday and the order and am very much obliged to you indeed the paper came totoo i was amused to read the account of the ball and the prince s prince's manovers maneuvers i should think by the account he behaved with great propriety and very good taste in his dress and his behavior) well walt Georgey aint ain't home yet i havent haven't heard a word from him since he went away the 1 of the month i think he might just write a line to me i expected he would be home last saturday Saturday but he dident didn't come so i suppose he will be here this saturSaturday

i haveenthaven't had no word from Jeffie nor martha since i wrote to you last week i sent a letter to Jeff yesterday neither have i had any word from han but that i dont don't think so strange of as she dont don't write more than once or twice in the year) helen price has been here and I gave her the paper with your peice piece in she was much pleased with it very much indeed she wished me to say to you she was obliged to you and received it as a christmas present she is working in that place i spoke about mr stitson i beleive believe his name is a lawyer of pattens patents she gets from to day today 8 dollars a week she has had 6
she is glad she can earn something she has given what she has earned to her mother but what she now gets she will get a nice black silk) i gess guess mrs price is like many others short of funds sometime walter my son this is the only envelope
i shall go down to the post office to day if it aint ain't slipery slippery
